sect1.title: Video Settings
sect1.para: Here we will configure all the settings related to the video input and output

sect2.title: Video Output
sect2.para: First, make sure you have the Xvideo extension actived in the X11 display:
The output should NOT contain "no adaptors present". If it's not activated, you may have to use a proprietary driver. See NvidiaSettings or AtiConfig for Nvidia and ATI cards respectively.
Next, what we want now is two video outputs. One for your monitor screen and one for your projector or video mixer.

For the nvidia graphic card, we have to detect both output. The first output (your monitor) is usually set to a 1024x768 resolution and the second output (VGA, or S-video Output) is usually set to a resolution of 800x600. Note that those resolution can vary from one setup to an other.
For this, follow our NvidiaSettings instructions.
Set the local machine display to output the video from the remote machine on the wanted monitor or TV.
The environment variable DISPLAY tells all X clients where to display their windows.
Ex: export DISPLAY=:0.0 will display the video on your local default screen. export DISPLAY=:0.1 will display the video on your second screen.

sect1.sect2:
Video Input
&app; can capture video from a video capture card through v4l2, from IIDC camera or DV camera (also called iLink). DV cameras and decks have a high latency (often between 150 and 250ms) and should not be the video input of choise for low latency requirements.
Video4Linux>
Plug in the video camera, for this, refer to our Hardware Setup Page
Now we will modify our video settings for your specific needs.
Firewire (DV or IIDC) Video Input
* The current user must be part of the disk and video groups. If that is not the case, then the system administrator must add the "user" to the "disk" group (as shown above)
On Karmic Koala, you have to fix devices attribution for raw1394. Create a udev rule to change group of /dev/raw1394 device: echo 'KERNEL=="raw1394", NAME="raw1394", GROUP="disk"' | sudo tee -a /etc/udev/rules.d/99-raw1394.rules sudo /etc/init.d/udev restart
Furthermore, on all distributions, it is advisable to load the raw1394 module even if no dc1394 cameras are present so that calls to libdc (i.e. milhouse --list-cameras) won't error out. To do this, add raw1394 to the /etc/modules file: sudo modprobe raw1394 echo "raw1394" | sudo tee -a /etc/modules
See this bug report for further information.
You can test the DV camera with:
gst-launch dv1394src ! dvdemux ! dvdec ! xvimagesink
